Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The use of Quantitative Geography to Predict Population Tipping Points for Colonial Seabirds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sub-meter resolution satellite imagery is a transformational technology that radically expands our ability to study the spatial ecology of colonial seabirds. At the same time, satellite imagery and the geospatial tools being developed to explore it present novel opportunities for earth and environmental science education. The research objective of this five-year project is to use individual-based models of nest site occupancy, parameterized by sub-meter satellite imagery, to estimate the relative importance of biotic and abiotic factors in structuring the fine-scale spatial ecology of seabird colonies (biological process) and to understand how these within-colony dynamics drive habitat occupancy at regional scales (geographic pattern). This project involves three interconnected research activities: 1) the synthesis of manual and automated algorithms for satellite imagery interpretation, and the use of such methods to create a high-resolution, large extent database of penguin breeding occupancy from which species-specific habitat suitability models will be developed; 2) the construction and parameterization of a hierarchical (species-specific) stochastic spatially-realistic structured metapopulation model to study the processes of colony formation and collapse. These models, parameterized by the sub-meter satellite imagery, will elucidate how tipping points at the local-scale drive emergent dynamics at the metapopulation scale; and 3) the optimization of spatial and/or temporal metrics for 'critical slowing' as an indication of impending seabird colony collapse and, at larger spatial scales, regional extinction.

The Broader Impacts of this project center around the development of secondary-school earth and environmental science learning modules that integrate geography (content), geospatial technologies (process), and virtual access to Antarctica (context) into a unified framework for teaching key components of the New York State Core Curricula for science. In addition to these modules, the project will involve paid summer internships for high school students to conduct independent research on Antarctic biogeography as part of New York's 'Science Research' curriculum. Finally, this project will provide research training for two Postdoctoral Researchers and two PhD students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project, we developed techniques to estimate penguin abundance using the guano (excrement) stain left behind at a penguin colony and used our mapping of penguin colonies to complete important surveys of the region and address several interesting questions regarding the spatial patterning of penguin colonies. This work has provided key information on the spatial structure and stability of penguin colonies and the links between very fine-scale spatial structure within a colony and larger-scale patterns of occupation across the Antarctic and associated islands.

The Intellectual Merit of the project derives from several accomplishments related to the use of satellite imagery for biological surveys in Antarctica, including a careful comparison of abundance estimates derived from high (sub-meter)-resolution satellite imagery and those derived from medium (30 m)-resolution Landsat imagery, the use of remote sensing in concert with field surveys for estimating penguin abundance in extremely remote but biologically important areas of Antarctica and associated islands, and the study of penguin colony colonization and extinction dynamics using satellite imagery. This project involved the first global survey of Adélie penguins using high-resolution commercial satellite imagery, which resulted in our finding that the Antarctic Adélie penguin population is 53% larger than expected. This survey, and the database that was created, provides a valuable baseline that can be used to track future changes in the species’ range. These techniques also led to the discovery of a major penguin hotspot in the Danger Islands, a small archipelago off the northern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. This series of penguin colonies was discovered first using Landsat imagery, then confirmed using high resolution commercial imagery, and was eventually surveyed using drones during the Dalio Foundation funded Danger Islands Expedition. 

A second major thrust of this project was the development of detailed simulations of penguin nesting within a penguin colony, parametrized by satellite and drone-based maps of real penguin colonies, to understand why penguin colonies form complex patterns on the landscape. This simulation allowed us to understand how the shapes of penguin colonies can tell us whether a population has been increasing or decreasing in abundance over time, which permits a rapid evaluation of abundance trends without the need for a long time series of direct population counts. This research has represented a unique opportunity to understand collective behavior that emerges over decades, and that can only be understood using the advanced imaging techniques developed under the auspices of this project.

Finally, this project also supported the first survey of king penguins on South Georgia, which was completed using a combination of satellite imagery and counts of panoramic photographs. This survey confirmed that the population of king penguins on South Georgia, an important center of king penguin abundance but one that had never been surveyed in its entirely, has grown rapidly over the last several decades.

While much of this project’s work has been focused on important basic science questions regarding the distribution and abundance of penguins, the research work has important Broader Impactsfor conservation in Antarctica. The discovery of a biological hotspot in the Danger Islands led to an expansion of the proposed Marine Protected Area for the western Antarctic Peninsula. This project has also generated significant public interest and has thus been a vehicle for communicating information about penguins and Antarctica to the wider public. Highlights include a segment on Sunday Night with Megyn Kelly, TV interviews on BBCNews, CBS, PBS Newshour, and Canada’s CTV, radio and podcast interviews with WHYY’s The Pulse, BBC5, and WPRI’s The World, and extensive coverage in outlets ranging from the New York Times,Washington Post, Wall Street Journal, Popular Mechanics, National Geographic Kids, and the Christian Science Monitor. This project also involved the development of activities for high school students, using penguins and penguin biogeography as a vehicle to teach kids about earth sciences more generally, as well as more specialized topics like Python programming and three-dimensional modelling.
